BIOS309
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
In this module we introduce concepts from ‘systems biology’. To do this, we will look at biological systems from the level of single-molecules, subcellular compartments, single-cells and through to whole organisms. Systematic approaches to biology often rely on ‘omics technologies. Through the lens of the biology underpinning individual papers, we will introduce transcriptomic/genomic, proteomic and metabolomic methods and how these methods influence the data we can obtain.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory modules to be coupled with practical exercises that involve analysis/interpretation/visualisation of example data sets.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course. Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise. Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
• To introduce methods to systems approaches underpinning modern biological research, using published manuscripts, and datasets as applied to studying biological questions from signalling pathways to whole organisms.

• To enable students to appreciate the variety of ‘omics methods used in systems biology and to use this data to understand biology.

• To train students in using 'omics data interpretation to understand a range of biological and biomedical systems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module examines how biology can be explored at scales from individual signalling pathways to whole organisms using methods and approaches from modern molecular systems biology. ‘Omics approaches including proteomics, genomics, transcriptomics and metabolomics are taught through the lens of these different experimental questions. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of molecular systems biology, investigate landmark papers using these different methods across different scales, and appreciate and the extent to which different investigative approaches and concepts are complementary to each other.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Systems Biology - An introduction
• Introducing the general area and concepts of systems biology, and the contrasts with alternative reductionist approaches to studying biology.

Topic 2: Biology Across Scales - How omics can be applied to study biological questions at scales ranging from pathways to single-cells to whole organisms.

Topic 3: Transcriptomics through the lens of biology – using published papers which exemplify the application of transcriptomics to biology
• Students will learn both how transcriptomics methods work, as well as how they can be applied to biology.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret transcriptomics datasets in computational classes, using datasets from papers discussed in class.

Topic 4: Genomics through the lens of biology
• The application of genomics to biology (for example, CRISPR screens) will be discussed,
• Methods for genomics to be understood, using papers which exemplify these methods.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret genomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 5: Proteomics through the lens of biology
• Study how LC-MS/MS-based proteomics works and how it can be applied to biological questions.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret proteomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 6: Metabolomics through the lens of biology
• Study metabolomic approaches in the context of papers exemplifying their application to biology.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret metabolomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 7: Integrating ‘omics data
• How to integrate multiple ‘omics approaches, for example integrating transcriptomics and proteomics to understand protein synthesis and turnover can yield biological insight, and the challenges with integrating multi-omics data.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be 4 x 3 hr workshops. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops allow the knowledge/concepts and datasets presented in the theory modules to be explored and applied in small groups and will use bioinformatic approaches, for example R.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include core theory, paper analysis, and discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Computer Workshops
Description: Application of lecture material using data to analyse, interpret and visualise
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry.

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignment.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

Self-directed learning: this module uses landmark papers to teach core areas of molecular systems biology. Students will need to read the set texts and will benefit from reading around the topics, with suggested additional reading provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.
Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Please approve this module. - Module review form with responses now updated.

In brief:

- LO’s updated in line with suggestions

- Visual communication added as a skill, in line with suggestions.

- Module assessment weighting was discussed, but we have kept the 40%/60% weighting rather than 50/50. based on our experience with current 3rd year teaching on LIFE303.

- Reading list cannot/should not be defined in the module spec, as this would ‘lock in’ what would rapidly become out of date papers in these rapidly moving fields.

BIOS309
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
In this module we introduce concepts from ‘systems biology’. To do this, we will look at biological systems from the level of single-molecules, subcellular compartments, single-cells and through to whole organisms. Systematic approaches to biology often rely on ‘omics technologies. Through the lens of the biology underpinning individual papers, we will introduce transcriptomic/genomic, proteomic and metabolomic methods and how these methods influence the data we can obtain.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory modules to be coupled with practical exercises that involve analysis/interpretation/visualisation of example data sets.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course. Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise. Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
• To introduce methods to systems approaches underpinning modern biological research, using published manuscripts, and datasets as applied to studying biological questions from signalling pathways to whole organisms.

• To enable students to appreciate the variety of ‘omics methods used in systems biology and to use this data to understand biology.

• To train students in using 'omics data interpretation to understand a range of biological and biomedical systems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module examines how biology can be explored at scales from individual signalling pathways to whole organisms using methods and approaches from modern molecular systems biology. ‘Omics approaches including proteomics, genomics, transcriptomics and metabolomics are taught through the lens of these different experimental questions. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of molecular systems biology, investigate landmark papers using these different methods across different scales, and appreciate and the extent to which different investigative approaches and concepts are complementary to each other.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Systems Biology - An introduction
• Introducing the general area and concepts of systems biology, and the contrasts with alternative reductionist approaches to studying biology.

Topic 2: Biology Across Scales - How omics can be applied to study biological questions at scales ranging from pathways to single-cells to whole organisms.

Topic 3: Transcriptomics through the lens of biology – using published papers which exemplify the application of transcriptomics to biology
• Students will learn both how transcriptomics methods work, as well as how they can be applied to biology.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret transcriptomics datasets in computational classes, using datasets from papers discussed in class.

Topic 4: Genomics through the lens of biology
• The application of genomics to biology (for example, CRISPR screens) will be discussed,
• Methods for genomics to be understood, using papers which exemplify these methods.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret genomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 5: Proteomics through the lens of biology
• Study how LC-MS/MS-based proteomics works and how it can be applied to biological questions.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret proteomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 6: Metabolomics through the lens of biology
• Study metabolomic approaches in the context of papers exemplifying their application to biology.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret metabolomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 7: Integrating ‘omics data
• How to integrate multiple ‘omics approaches, for example integrating transcriptomics and proteomics to understand protein synthesis and turnover can yield biological insight, and the challenges with integrating multi-omics data.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be 4 x 3 hr workshops. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops allow the knowledge/concepts and datasets presented in the theory modules to be explored and applied in small groups and will use bioinformatic approaches, for example R.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include core theory, paper analysis, and discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Computer Workshops
Description: Application of lecture material using data to analyse, interpret and visualise
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry.

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignment.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

Self-directed learning: this module uses landmark papers to teach core areas of molecular systems biology. Students will need to read the set texts and will benefit from reading around the topics, with suggested additional reading provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.
Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome

 LO3 Critically evaluate the principles of molecular systems biology and apply this to solve problems in biological science.

Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.
Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS309
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
In this module we introduce concepts from ‘systems biology’. To do this, we will look at biological systems from the level of single-molecules, subcellular compartments, single-cells and through to whole organisms. Systematic approaches to biology often rely on ‘omics technologies. Through the lens of the biology underpinning individual papers, we will introduce transcriptomic/genomic, proteomic and metabolomic methods and how these methods influence the data we can obtain.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The workshops allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory modules to be coupled with practical exercises that involve analysis/interpretation/visualisation of example data sets.

The module will be assessed via two assessments that involve data interpretation and application to the key concepts/techniques covered in the course. Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise. Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
• To introduce methods to systems approaches underpinning modern biological research, using published manuscripts, and datasets as applied to studying biological questions from signalling pathways to whole organisms.

• To enable students to appreciate the variety of ‘omics methods used in systems biology and to use this data to understand biology.

• To train students in using 'omics data interpretation to understand a range of biological and biomedical systems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module examines how biology can be explored at scales from individual signalling pathways to whole organisms using methods and approaches from modern molecular systems biology. ‘Omics approaches including proteomics, genomics, transcriptomics and metabolomics are taught through the lens of these different experimental questions. Throughout, students will evaluate the field of molecular systems biology, investigate landmark papers using these different methods across different scales, and appreciate and the extent to which different investigative approaches and concepts are complementary to each other.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Systems Biology - An introduction
• Introducing the general area and concepts of systems biology, and the contrasts with alternative reductionist approaches to studying biology.

Topic 2: Biology Across Scales - How omics can be applied to study biological questions at scales ranging from pathways to single-cells to whole organisms.

Topic 3: Transcriptomics through the lens of biology – using published papers which exemplify the application of transcriptomics to biology
• Students will learn both how transcriptomics methods work, as well as how they can be applied to biology.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret transcriptomics datasets in computational classes, using datasets from papers discussed in class.

Topic 4: Genomics through the lens of biology
• The application of genomics to biology (for example, CRISPR screens) will be discussed,
• Methods for genomics to be understood, using papers which exemplify these methods.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret genomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 5: Proteomics through the lens of biology
• Study how LC-MS/MS-based proteomics works and how it can be applied to biological questions.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret proteomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 6: Metabolomics through the lens of biology
• Study metabolomic approaches in the context of papers exemplifying their application to biology.
• Students will learn how to handle & interpret metabolomics datasets in computational classes.

Topic 7: Integrating ‘omics data
• How to integrate multiple ‘omics approaches, for example integrating transcriptomics and proteomics to understand protein synthesis and turnover can yield biological insight, and the challenges with integrating multi-omics data.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week consists of 3 x 50 min interactive lectures and throughout the module there will be 4 x 3 hr workshops. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops allow the knowledge/concepts and datasets presented in the theory modules to be explored and applied in small groups and will use bioinformatic approaches, for example R.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include core theory, paper analysis, and discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 – Computer Workshops
Description: Application of lecture material using data to analyse, interpret and visualise
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry.

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignment.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

Self-directed learning: this module uses landmark papers to teach core areas of molecular systems biology. Students will need to read the set texts and will benefit from reading around the topics, with suggested additional reading provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a short answer exercise based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.
Assessment 2 (60%) will be an extended written exercise across the whole course based around molecular systems biology concepts and data interpretation.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Formative assessment opportunities will be provided.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
